   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "6e10598e-3e27-4d3e-94ba-407910c354e5",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "### Bar Plots\n",
    "‚ùì **Key Question:**\n",
    "**Do misinformation tweets follow a weekly pattern?**  \n",
    "Are certain days more prone to misinformation spread, or is engagement consistent throughout the week?\n",
    "\n",
    "---\n",
    "\n",
    "üìå Why This Matters:  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Understanding tweet frequency by day** helps identify **high-risk days** for misinformation.    \n",
    "‚úÖ **Social media habits vary** ‚Äì More activity on certain days (e.g., workdays vs. weekends).    \n",
    "‚úÖ If misinformation tweets peak on specific days, **fact-checking efforts** can be better timed.\n",
    "\n",
    "---"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 158,
   "id": "b12d67db-2e8a-45b2-9cd0-26a71c6f851f",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 1000x500 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "# Count tweets per day of the week\n",
    "day_counts = df['day_name'].value_counts().reindex([\"Monday\", \"Tuesday\", \"Wednesday\", \"Thursday\", \"Friday\", \"Saturday\", \"Sunday\"])\n",
    "\n",
    "# Plot bar chart\n",
    "plt.figure(figsize=(10, 5))\n",
    "sns.barplot(x=day_counts.index, y=day_counts.values)\n",
    "\n",
    "# Labeling\n",
    "plt.title(\"Number of Tweets by Day of the Week\", fontsize=14)\n",
    "plt.xlabel(\"Day of the Week\", fontsize=12)\n",
    "plt.ylabel(\"Number of Tweets\", fontsize=12)\n",
    "plt.show()\n"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "64230848-63ab-4cb0-8050-aa48ca2a0f3c",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "This bar chart shows the **number of tweets per day**, helping us understand when misinformation tweets are most frequent.\n",
    "\n",
    "üîç **Key Insights:**\n",
    "\n",
    "‚úÖ **Which days see the most misinformation?** ‚Äì Are certain days more prone to misinformation spread?  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Does engagement align with tweet volume?** ‚Äì Does a high number of tweets correlate with increased likes/shares?  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Weekend vs. Weekday Trends** ‚Äì Are misinformation tweets more frequent on weekends?  \n",
    "\n",
    "üîç **Analysis: What Does This Show?**\n",
    "\n",
    "‚úÖ Higher tweet volume on weekdays ‚Äì Tweets are more frequent from Monday to Friday, peaking mid-week.  \n",
    "‚úÖ Lower engagement on weekends ‚Äì Saturday and Sunday see a noticeable drop in tweets.  \n",
    "‚úÖ Potential reasons for these trends:\n",
    "\n",
    "- Workdays might encourage more online discussions.\n",
    "- Weekends could reflect less misinformation production or moderation gaps.\n",
    "- Certain misinformation topics (e.g., politics, health) may trend more on weekdays.\n",
    "---"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "fb2876ac-4818-4a69-aba7-166b61919099",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "### Pie Chart  \n",
    "‚ùì **Key Question:**  \n",
    "**Do misinformation tweets follow a time-of-day pattern?**  \n",
    "Are certain periods (morning, afternoon, evening, night) more prone to misinformation activity?\n",
    "\n",
    "---\n",
    "\n",
    "üìå **Why This Matters:**  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Understanding when misinformation is most active** helps identify **high-risk periods**.  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Social media engagement varies throughout the day** ‚Äì Different times may see different types of users.  \n",
    "‚úÖ If misinformation peaks at certain hours, **fact-checking and moderation efforts** can be optimized."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 160,
   "id": "f19d31a7-1cf7-457a-a409-4972019ec9fd",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 700x700 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "# Count occurrences of each time of day\n",
    "time_counts = df['time_of_day'].value_counts()\n",
    "\n",
    "# Create pie chart\n",
    "plt.figure(figsize=(7, 7))\n",
    "plt.pie(time_counts, labels=time_counts.index, autopct='%1.1f%%', colors=['#3498db', '#2ecc71', '#e74c3c', '#f39c12'])\n",
    "plt.title(\"Tweet Distribution by Time of Day\")\n",
    "plt.show()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "5501bb9b-bd0f-4313-8736-f37a9aaa95da",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "This pie chart shows the **distribution of tweets across different times of the day**, helping us determine when misinformation is most active.\n",
    "\n",
    "üîç **Key Insights:**  \n",
    "\n",
    "‚úÖ **Which time period sees the most tweets?** ‚Äì Are misinformation tweets more frequent at night or during work hours?  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Does engagement match tweet volume?** ‚Äì Do people interact more during peak misinformation hours?  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Do patterns align with social media habits?** ‚Äì Does misinformation spread more when people are commuting, working, or relaxing?\n",
    "\n",
    "üîç **Analysis: What Does This Show?**  \n",
    "\n",
    "‚úÖ **Night has the highest tweet volume (30.8%)** ‚Äì This suggests that misinformation may spread more during **late hours**, possibly when fewer moderators are active.  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Morning and Afternoon tweets are also significant (26.4% & 24.3%)** ‚Äì These periods align with **peak social media usage** during work breaks.  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Evening has the lowest tweet share (18.5%)** ‚Äì This could indicate reduced social media activity or a shift toward **consuming rather than sharing content**.\n",
    "\n",
    "**Potential Explanations:**  \n",
    "- Nighttime misinformation surges may be due to **reduced content moderation** or **global audiences in different time zones**.  \n",
    "- Misinformation in the morning and afternoon may reflect **news cycles and trending topics**.  \n",
    "- Different types of misinformation (political, health-related) may peak at different times.\n",
    "\n",
    "---"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "81ea74b4-8911-414c-88f0-def9e2487e9c",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "### Histogram  \n",
    "‚ùì **Key Question:**  \n",
    "**Do misinformation tweets show seasonal trends?**  \n",
    "Are misinformation tweets more frequent in specific months, or is tweet activity evenly distributed throughout the year?\n",
    "\n",
    "---\n",
    "\n",
    "üìå **Why This Matters:**  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Detecting seasonal patterns** ‚Äì Do misinformation tweets increase during elections, health crises, or other global events?  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Understanding user behavior** ‚Äì Do social media users post more misinformation during certain times of the year?  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Anticipating misinformation surges** ‚Äì Identifying patterns can help prepare countermeasures for high-activity periods.\n",
    "\n",
    "---"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 56,
   "id": "859225b3-3b6e-49d3-92f2-20e810b03e90",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 1000x500 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n",
    "import seaborn as sns\n",
    "\n",
    "# Set seaborn style\n",
    "sns.set_theme(style=\"whitegrid\")\n",
    "\n",
    "# Plot histogram of tweets by month\n",
    "plt.figure(figsize=(10, 5))\n",
    "sns.histplot(df['month'], bins=12, discrete=True, kde=False, color='#3498db')\n",
    "\n",
    "# Labeling\n",
    "plt.title(\"Tweet Distribution by Month\", fontsize=14)\n",
    "plt.xlabel(\"Month\", fontsize=12)\n",
    "plt.ylabel(\"Number of Tweets\", fontsize=12)\n",
    "plt.xticks(ticks=range(1, 13), labels=['Jan', 'Feb', 'Mar', 'Apr', 'May', 'Jun', 'Jul', 'Aug', 'Sep', 'Oct', 'Nov', 'Dec'])\n",
    "plt.show()\n"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "b25606c2-2bcb-4f53-972e-a93a3342a9ff",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "This histogram visualizes the **distribution of tweets by month**, helping us identify trends in misinformation spread over the year.\n",
    "\n",
    "üîç **Key Insights:**  \n",
    "\n",
    "‚úÖ **Are misinformation tweets evenly distributed across months?** ‚Äì Or do they cluster at specific times of the year?  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Are there months with noticeable spikes?** ‚Äì Do misinformation tweets increase due to major events or seasonal factors?  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Are there months with lower misinformation activity?** ‚Äì Does misinformation dip during certain periods?\n",
    "\n",
    "üîç **Analysis: What Does This Show?**  \n",
    "\n",
    "‚úÖ **High tweet volume in January and February** ‚Äì Possible connection to **New Year events, political developments, or global discussions**.  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Low misinformation activity in May and September** ‚Äì Could indicate periods of reduced misinformation spread or lower engagement.  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Fluctuations throughout the year** ‚Äì Suggests that misinformation surges **are event-driven rather than constant**.\n",
    "\n",
    "**Potential Explanations:**  \n",
    "- Political events, elections, or crises might trigger **misinformation spikes** in specific months.  \n",
    "- Some misinformation campaigns could be **seasonal** (e.g., health-related misinformation in flu season).  \n",
    "- Variations in tweet volume might also reflect **changes in platform moderation or fact-checking efforts**.\n",
    "\n",
    "---"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "b6daad96-7c89-4497-bdbf-c7f045de2031",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "### Boxplot  \n",
    "‚ùì **Key Question:**  \n",
    "**How are likes distributed across misinformation tweets?**  \n",
    "Are there extreme variations in engagement, and do outliers suggest viral tweets?\n",
    "\n",
    "---\n",
    "\n",
    "üìå **Why This Matters:**  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Identifies engagement distribution** ‚Äì Are most tweets getting similar engagement, or is there high variability?  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Detects outliers (viral tweets)** ‚Äì Do a few tweets receive disproportionately high likes?  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Helps decide on data transformations** ‚Äì If data is skewed, should we apply a log transformation for better analysis?\n",
    "\n",
    "---"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 57,
   "id": "15eedded-5c6a-46d4-85c6-b5437a128c1c",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 800x500 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "# Set seaborn style\n",
    "sns.set_theme(style=\"whitegrid\")\n",
    "\n",
    "# Create boxplot\n",
    "plt.figure(figsize=(8, 5))\n",
    "sns.boxplot(x=df['likes'], color='#3498db')\n",
    "\n",
    "# Labeling\n",
    "plt.title(\"Boxplot of Likes\", fontsize=14)\n",
    "plt.xlabel(\"Number of Likes\", fontsize=12)\n",
    "plt.show()\n"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "afcb455b-1d40-40ee-82b2-91d249691581",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "This boxplot visualizes the **distribution of likes on misinformation tweets**, highlighting the central tendency, spread, and presence of extreme values.\n",
    "\n",
    "üîç **Key Insights:**  \n",
    "\n",
    "‚úÖ **Is engagement concentrated around a certain range?** ‚Äì Or does it vary significantly across tweets?  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Are there many outliers?** ‚Äì The presence of extreme values (far beyond the box) suggests some tweets go viral.  \n",
    "‚úÖ **How does the median compare to the spread?** ‚Äì If the median is very low compared to the upper whisker, likes may be highly skewed.\n",
    "\n",
    "üîç **Analysis: What Does This Show?**  \n",
    "\n",
    "‚úÖ **Most tweets receive very few likes** ‚Äì The central box is compressed toward **lower engagement values**.  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Significant outliers (viral tweets)** ‚Äì Many individual points far from the whiskers indicate that **a few tweets received massive engagement**.  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Highly skewed distribution** ‚Äì Most tweets have **low engagement**, but a **small percentage go viral**, leading to an uneven spread.\n",
    "\n",
    "**Potential Explanations:**  \n",
    "- Misinformation might have **low baseline engagement** but **occasional viral tweets** amplify its reach.  \n",
    "- Engagement could depend on **influencers or amplification efforts** (e.g., bots, coordinated sharing).  \n",
    "- A log transformation might help **normalize the distribution** for better statistical analysis.\n",
    "\n",
    "---"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "2c75f465-7017-47be-abeb-c6d26dc57f70",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "### Scatter Plot  \n",
    "‚ùì **Key Question:**  \n",
    "**Is there a correlation between likes and shares on misinformation tweets?**  \n",
    "Do tweets with more likes also receive more shares, or is the relationship weak?\n",
    "\n",
    "---\n",
    "\n",
    "üìå **Why This Matters:**  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Understanding engagement behavior** ‚Äì Do users who like misinformation tweets also share them?  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Detecting viral content patterns** ‚Äì Are high-like tweets more likely to be widely shared?  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Identifying amplification strategies** ‚Äì Are misinformation tweets pushed by coordinated efforts, or is sharing organic?\n",
    "\n",
    "---"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 163,
   "id": "bf9ab315-891c-4bdd-a76b-aafc4746e8ea",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 800x600 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "# Set seaborn style\n",
    "sns.set_theme(style=\"whitegrid\")\n",
    "\n",
    "# Create scatter plot\n",
    "plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6))\n",
    "sns.scatterplot(x=df['likes'], y=df['shares'], alpha=0.5, color='#3498db')\n",
    "\n",
    "# Labeling\n",
    "plt.title(\"Scatter Plot of Likes vs. Shares\", fontsize=14)\n",
    "plt.xlabel(\"Number of Likes\", fontsize=12)\n",
    "plt.ylabel(\"Number of Shares\", fontsize=12)\n",
    "plt.show()\n"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "2869bd50-6c2f-41e4-8565-5d96d2ed2921",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "This scatter plot visualizes the **relationship between likes and shares on misinformation tweets**, helping us assess whether high engagement in one metric predicts high engagement in the other.\n",
    "\n",
    "üîç **Key Insights:**  \n",
    "\n",
    "‚úÖ **Is there a positive correlation?** ‚Äì Do tweets with more likes tend to have more shares?  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Are there separate engagement clusters?** ‚Äì Are some tweets heavily liked but rarely shared, or vice versa?  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Are outliers (viral tweets) present?** ‚Äì Do some tweets have extreme values in either direction?\n",
    "\n",
    "üîç **Analysis: What Does This Show?**  \n",
    "\n",
    "‚úÖ **Most tweets have low engagement** ‚Äì A dense cluster in the bottom-left suggests that **many tweets get very few likes and shares**.  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Some tweets achieve high engagement** ‚Äì A smaller subset of tweets shows **both high likes and high shares**, likely indicating **viral content**.  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Correlation appears weak but present** ‚Äì While more likes **generally** lead to more shares, the relationship is **not perfectly linear**, suggesting that some tweets get **liked a lot but not widely shared**.\n",
    "\n",
    "**Potential Explanations:**  \n",
    "- Some misinformation tweets may encourage **engagement through likes but not sharing**, limiting their spread.  \n",
    "- Virality may depend on **other factors** (e.g., influencer amplification, trending topics, algorithmic boosts).  \n",
    "- Further analysis could explore **engagement rate per follower** or **time-based engagement trends**.\n",
    "\n",
    "---"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "e0a510a2-a809-41c1-b6ec-98093cafcf27",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "### Line Plot  \n",
    "‚ùì **Key Question:**  \n",
    "**When do misinformation tweets receive the most engagement?**  \n",
    "Are there specific hours of the day when likes, shares, and comments peak?\n",
    "\n",
    "---\n",
    "\n",
    "üìå **Why This Matters:**  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Identifies peak engagement hours** ‚Äì Knowing when users interact most with misinformation can help develop countermeasures.  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Analyzes user behavior** ‚Äì Understanding whether engagement is higher during work hours, evenings, or late nights can provide insights into audience activity.  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Optimizes content moderation strategies** ‚Äì Platforms can allocate fact-checking resources more efficiently during peak misinformation engagement times.\n",
    "\n",
    "---"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 59,
   "id": "f6af6fa5-0ff6-44bb-878e-c4a8f224ffe5",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 1200x600 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "# Average engagement per hour of the day\n",
    "hourly_engagement = df.groupby('hour').agg({'likes': 'mean', 'shares': 'mean', 'comments': 'mean'}).reset_index()\n",
    "\n",
    "# Plot\n",
    "plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))\n",
    "sns.lineplot(data=hourly_engagement, x='hour', y='likes', label='Likes', marker='o', color='blue')\n",
    "sns.lineplot(data=hourly_engagement, x='hour', y='shares', label='Shares', marker='o', color='green')\n",
    "sns.lineplot(data=hourly_engagement, x='hour', y='comments', label='Comments', marker='o', color='red')\n",
    "\n",
    "plt.title(\"Average Engagement by Hour of Day\")\n",
    "plt.xlabel(\"Hour of the Day\")\n",
    "plt.ylabel(\"Average Engagement\")\n",
    "plt.xticks(range(0, 24))\n",
    "plt.legend()\n",
    "plt.show()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "e1d43ba9-b085-4268-9f54-6bf6cd4ca13d",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "This line plot visualizes the **average engagement (likes, shares, comments) for misinformation tweets at different hours of the day**, helping us detect high-risk periods.\n",
    "\n",
    "üîç **Key Insights:**  \n",
    "\n",
    "‚úÖ **When does engagement peak?** ‚Äì Are likes, shares, and comments more common in the morning, afternoon, or late night?  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Are different engagement types following the same trend?** ‚Äì Do likes, shares, and comments increase simultaneously, or do they behave differently?  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Are there off-peak hours?** ‚Äì Do certain hours consistently show lower engagement?\n",
    "\n",
    "üîç **Analysis: What Does This Show?**  \n",
    "\n",
    "‚úÖ **Likes peak in the late night (around 23:00)** ‚Äì This suggests that misinformation tweets **may receive the most passive engagement (likes) during late hours**.  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Shares and comments are more stable** ‚Äì Unlike likes, shares and comments follow a **flatter trend** throughout the day, but with some fluctuations.  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Engagement dips occur during mid-morning and early afternoon** ‚Äì Lower interaction between **10:00 and 14:00** may indicate reduced activity during working hours.\n",
    "\n",
    "**Potential Explanations:**  \n",
    "- **Late-night engagement surges** could be due to **users scrolling before bedtime**, when **critical thinking might be lower**.  \n",
    "- **Shares and comments may not correlate perfectly with likes**, suggesting different engagement motivations.  \n",
    "- **Moderation and fact-checking efforts may need to be reinforced in the late evening**, when misinformation engagement appears highest.\n",
    "\n",
    "---"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "02b83708-f09a-4c96-b42e-a4763e1949a0",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "### Line Plot 2\n",
    "‚ùì **Key Question:**  \n",
    "**How has engagement with misinformation tweets changed over time?**  \n",
    "Are there noticeable spikes in likes, shares, and comments that correlate with real-world events?\n",
    "\n",
    "---\n",
    "\n",
    "üìå **Why This Matters:**  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Identifies trends in misinformation engagement** ‚Äì Do engagement levels rise and fall cyclically or remain steady?  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Detects viral misinformation events** ‚Äì Large spikes may indicate misinformation surges tied to major news or political events.  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Informs counter-misinformation efforts** ‚Äì Understanding engagement trends helps allocate resources for content moderation and fact-checking.\n",
    "\n",
    "---"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 164,
   "id": "e9112ffc-77b0-4150-8ef5-9abbe31f5ef9",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 1200x600 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "# Convert timestamp to datetime if not already done\n",
    "df['timestamp'] = pd.to_datetime(df['timestamp'], errors='coerce')\n",
    "\n",
    "# Aggregate engagement by day\n",
    "time_engagement = df.groupby(df['timestamp'].dt.date).agg({'likes': 'sum', 'shares': 'sum', 'comments': 'sum'}).reset_index()\n",
    "\n",
    "# Plot engagement over time\n",
    "plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))\n",
    "plt.plot(time_engagement['timestamp'], time_engagement['likes'], label='Likes', color='blue')\n",
    "plt.plot(time_engagement['timestamp'], time_engagement['shares'], label='Shares', color='green')\n",
    "plt.plot(time_engagement['timestamp'], time_engagement['comments'], label='Comments', color='red')\n",
    "\n",
    "plt.title(\"Engagement Trends Over Time\")\n",
    "plt.xlabel(\"Date\")\n",
    "plt.ylabel(\"Total Engagement\")\n",
    "plt.legend()\n",
    "plt.xticks(rotation=45)\n",
    "plt.show()\n"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "bc3fda37-97c3-4f6c-87b5-7e0e030f79a8",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "This line plot visualizes **the total engagement (likes, shares, and comments) on misinformation tweets over time**, helping us identify significant peaks and long-term patterns.\n",
    "\n",
    "üîç **Key Insights:**  \n",
    "\n",
    "‚úÖ **Are engagement levels stable or fluctuating?** ‚Äì Do likes, shares, and comments follow a consistent trend, or do they vary significantly?  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Do all engagement types behave similarly?** ‚Äì Are spikes in likes always accompanied by spikes in shares and comments, or do they follow different patterns?  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Are there distinct peaks?** ‚Äì Do certain dates show extreme engagement levels, indicating potential misinformation events?\n",
    "\n",
    "üîç **Analysis: What Does This Show?**  \n",
    "\n",
    "‚úÖ **Frequent spikes in engagement** ‚Äì The presence of many sharp peaks suggests that **misinformation engagement is event-driven rather than steady**.  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Likes dominate engagement trends** ‚Äì Blue (likes) consistently reaches the highest levels, suggesting that users are **more likely to like misinformation than share or comment on it**.  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Some extreme outliers** ‚Äì Occasional **major spikes** in engagement may correlate with **specific misinformation campaigns, trending topics, or political events**.\n",
    "\n",
    "**Potential Explanations:**  \n",
    "- Peaks may coincide with **pandemic misinformation waves, elections, or geopolitical crises** that drive engagement.  \n",
    "- Likes are **easier than shares/comments**, leading to more passive engagement rather than active amplification.  \n",
    "- Future analysis could focus on **annotating peaks with real-world events** to better understand misinformation drivers.\n",
    "\n",
    "---"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "711e59f1-8a3b-4e05-94a3-6f4f36f8bd9f",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "üéØ **Lesson Summary & Key Takeaways**  \n",
    "\n",
    "In this lesson, we walked through the **critical thinking process** behind exploratory data analysis (EDA) and applied it to **misinformation engagement metrics**.  \n",
    "\n",
    "**üîç What We Covered:**  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Understanding Our Data** ‚Äì Examining dataset structure, data types, and missing values.  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Feature Engineering** ‚Äì Extracting meaningful insights from timestamps.  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Visualizing Trends** ‚Äì Exploring misinformation engagement patterns over time.  \n",
    "‚úÖ **Detecting Relationships** ‚Äì Identifying correlations between likes, shares, and comments.  \n",
    "\n",
    "**üí° Key Reflections:**  \n",
    "- **What patterns did we uncover?** Did engagement vary by time, or were there consistent trends?  \n",
    "- **What surprised you?** Did the data reveal anything unexpected about misinformation spread?  \n",
    "- **What should we analyze further?** Are there additional variables that could impact engagement?  \n",
    "\n",
    "---\n",
    "\n",
    "**üöÄ Next Steps: Your Assignment**\n",
    "Now that you've seen an example EDA walkthrough, it's time for you to **apply these concepts** to another dataset.\n",
    "\n",
    "---\n",
    "\n",
    "üîé **Let‚Äôs move forward!** "
